major_name: Bachelor of Applied Science Degree Requirements
topics: Notice of Recording
Economics and Sustainability Winter 2025
DWE 1515
In the case of inclement weather, course lectures may shift online.
View requirements for ERS 320
We cover multiple perspectives in economics and trace the evolution of key drivers, debates, and policy approaches before turning to new frontiers of research and practice.

The course format combines interactive lectures with exercises to build skills in economic and policy analysis, technical writing (policy briefings) for specialized audiences, and data analysis and visualization.

The term will culminate in a poster session on sustainable economic futures with a focus on water, climate, and biodiversity - three areas where economists have prepared major reviews in the last 15 years.
Describe and compare different economic perspectives on sustainability and development
Identify trends and debates on the economics of sustainability from a systems perspective;
Evaluate the strengths and weaknesses of economic methodologies for policy analysis;
Integrate economic ideas and methods with other disciplinary perspectives in the humanities, natural sciences, engineering sciences and social sciences
Introduction
Why economics matters for sustainability
The evolution of economic ideas about sustainability
Sustainability economics
Markets and the commons
Why and how markets fail; coordination problems; property rights
Valuing nature
Frameworks and methods for valuing the environment
How institutions and incentives shape behaviour and policy
Defining and applying key concepts
The Economics of Safe Drinking Water
Atlas of Water Markets: East Africa and Latin America
Natural Monopolies & Negative Externalities
Atlas of Water Markets: South Asia, Southern Europe & North Africa
The Economics of Biodiversity and Climate Adaptation
Atlas of Water Markets: Western USA and Australia
New frontiers of economic thinking about sustainability
Summit
Students are expected to attend each class and participate in three ways: critical reading; active engagement in class discussions and debates; and completion of practical exercises during tutorials.
The mid-term exam, held Feb 26th, will be an in-class exam assessing understanding of core concepts and debates.
The format will include multiple choice and short essays.
Each student will be tasked with completing a policy briefing that applies economic concepts and methods to identify the causes of a water sustainability challenge and outline potential solutions.

major_name: Bachelor of Applied Science Degree Requirements
topics: Religion in Popular Film Fall 2024
This course examines how religion has been a central concern and inspiration for filmmakers and how popular films have informed and shaped our understanding of religion.
FINE 252: View requirements for FINE 252
Religion reflects both humankind's search for meaning and its attempts to maintain particular meanings in the face of cultural challenge and social pressure.
We use them as ways of establishing shared interests and in-groups, as well as exploring questions both mundane and momentous.

As our culture passes relentlessly from literacy to visuality, discerning how the various dimensions of religious belief and practice are reflected and refracted in film and television is an important element in understanding the nature of religion in late modern society.
Engage in critical dialogue with these texts and experiences, with scholars who have contributed to their interpretation, and with each other;
Improve communication skills through written assignments and class participation; and continue to foster skills in critical thinking and analysis.

course_name: GEOG101 - Human Geographies: People, Space and Change (0.50)
major_name: Bachelor of Applied Science Degree Requirements
topics: E-mail: bdoberst@uwaterloo.ca

An introduction to human geography through key subfields of the discipline, examining population change, the rise of cities, our relationship to nature, social inequalities, economic forms, cultural difference and environmental change at the local and global scale.
So-called “food geography” is then explored, followed by an examination of the geographic basis of patterns of urbanization, and an exploration of global economic activity.

The course concludes with a short unit on hazards geography, analysis of global development patterns and processes, and an assessment of human impacts on and sustainability in terrestrial and marine environments.
For Winter 2025, course content will be delivered through a combination of in-class lectures and self-viewed readings and videos.
Compare and contrast Human Geography theory with real-world expressions of Human Geography
Construct solutions which apply Human Geography concepts and skills to real-world sustainability problems

Food deserts, food miles & lower impact food

Urban Sustainability
Urbanization in Developing Countries/Informal settlements
Economic Geography

course_name: GEOG349 - Urban Form and Spatial Structure (0.50)
major_name: Bachelor of Applied Science Degree Requirements
topics: An examination of the major factors giving rise to distinctive styles of urban spatial organization.
The best planning practices from developing countries are being used in some western industrialized countries, and vice versa.

Based on current globalization and learning from best planning practices worldwide, this course will offer comparative analysis of urban spatial structure and urban form, as well as administrative and regulatory implications of urbanization around world.
Be aware of the evolution of the urban systems in each world region
Understand the common urban problems and their possible solutions in many cities
Become familiar with urban form and internal urban structure and how they may be demonstrated in different world cities
Appreciate a comprehensive set of tools for understanding the changing urban forms
Become familiar with critical thinking in urban problems and internal structure
They can expect to learn the elements of clear thinking and to be nurtured in their development to be careful, critical, and innovative thinkers.

Global knowledge of urban issues and overseas experience: Students should be able to demonstrate an awareness of the environmental, economic, social diversities and interdependences that exist among nations and regions.
Advanced writing skills: Students should be able to communicate ideas clearly and cogently.
General Introduction – World Urban Development; Concepts and Definitions
Introduction to Cities.
Introduction to Cities.
WEEK 3. Cities of Middle America; Cities and Systems
World cities under conditions of financialized globalization: Towards an augmented world city hypothesis.
Introduction to Cities.
Chapter 3: Social Theories of Urban Space and Place: Perspectives in the Post-World War II era.
Introduction to Cities.
Recommended readings: Introduction to Cities.
Inequality and Diversity in the Post-World War II Metropolis.
Introduction to Cities.
Cities of Sub-Saharan Africa; Integrated transportation and land use planning
Introduction to Cities.

Introduction to Cities.

Cities of East Asia; Urban heritage and conservation planning
Heritage conservation and the politics of difference.
Heritage conservation through planning: A comparison of policies and principles in England and China.
Cities of Australia and the Pacific Islands; Urban Poverty Alleviation
Financial development and poverty reduction nexus: A cointegration and causality analysis in Bangladesh.
The track of this global expedition weaves through nine major regions of the world, exploring significant urban patterns, processes, and internal spatial structure.
Students are asked to relate the principles of sustainable urban forms to the reflections, since these principles provide a powerful framework for constructing ideas and discussions.
The concept of urban form and principles of sustainable urban forms should be discussed in the assignment.
A strong reflection will summarize key course concepts and principles and apply them to personal experience and perceptions.

Discuss how these experiences have shaped your awareness of the impact of certain urban forms on people’s experience with cities in the countries that we cover in Week 2 to Week 4, your personal values, and your approach to planning/geography.
Formatting:
Problem-solving mentalities and skills are crucial for planners and geographers.

These five categories of tools include 1) planning and building regulation (e.g. intensification); 2) fiscal and non-fiscal incentivization (e.g. special economic zone); 3) direct provision by public and/or voluntary sectors (e.g. public sector involvement); 4) education and awareness-raising (e.g. planning-related open houses); and 5) promotion of behavioral change (e.g. pedestrian friendly public space and TOD design).
Please note that students must focus on one planning tool for an in-depth evaluation, even if multiple tools are involved in the chosen case.
A strong report will comprehensively evaluate the chosen planning tool (including its functions, implementations, strengths and weaknesses, and socioeconomic consequences).
Introduction (2 marks)
A brief and general reflection on the comprehension and implementations of planning tools (3 marks)
At least five references regarding the chosen planning tool should be cited.

course_name: GEOG368 - Ecology and Conservation for Planning (0.50)
major_name: Bachelor of Applied Science Degree Requirements
topics: Ecology and Conservation for Planning Winter 2025
This course provides students with a critical understanding of the relationship between human development and natural environments.
Students will develop an understanding of core ecological principles and how these can be taken up in plans and policies to promote nature conservation in urban and rural environments.

The course will include examples of how planners mitigate the environmental impacts of development of land, allotment of open space and parks, and conservation of sensitive areas and species in both urban and rural contexts.

major_name: Bachelor of Applied Science Degree Requirements
topics: Email:                                       daniel.cockayne@uwaterloo.ca
Email:               s32zaman@uwaterloo.ca

Beginning with the infrastructures that supports digital systems and entrepreneurship, and with a close focus on entrepreneurial digital media production in Silicon Valley, this course explores the numerous ways that digital systems implicate economic systems, examining social media, attention economies, the sharing economy, digital work platforms, and influencer economies.
Describe the digital infrastructures and systems that support the digital economy and the geographic histories of their emergence.
Critically analyze the economic systems that are necessary conditions for modern-day digital media technologies.
Theorize these phenomena in relation to geographical concepts including the international division of labor and difference in the global economy.
Topics and reading
Introduction of the course topics, assignments, and expectations.
Producing The Digital Economy I: Silicon Valley & San Francisco
How do we measure ‘success’ in the digital media sector?
Recode/Decode
Producing The Digital Economy II: Venture Capital and Inequality
What are some of the historical and structural implications of venture capital as a financial mechanism?
Rethinking the venture capital model.
Social Media and Attention Economies
Advertising and data allow these companies to run - how do they keep people interested?
What are some of the perhaps unintended impacts of the rise of social media?
The Culture of Connectivity: A Critical History of Social Media.
The Gig Economy - Uber and Airbnb
How have ‘gig economy’ platforms like Uber and Airbnb changed sectors and industries?
Are these platforms really different from prior forms of economic activity?
How does the gig economy relate to concepts like precarity?
Algorithmic labor and information asymmetries: a case study of Uber drivers.
The internet allows people to create personas online, and many have found ways to monetize these platforms for themselves, through procuring idealized performances of the self.
Streamers and influencers make money through sponsorship and through cuts of platforms’ ad revenue.
What are some of the implications of these shifts?
Self-enterprising eSports: Meritocracy, precarity, and disposability of eSports players in China.
What are some of the darker sides of entrepreneurship and privilege that characterize a many digital companies?
How do these factors affect and implicated offline economies too?
Content and readings TBD
Short Analytical Essay Due
Producing Digital Economies III: Work Platforms and The Planetary Labor Market
Difference and dependence amongst digital workers: the case of Amazon Mechanical Turk.
These networks are essential for the functioning of the digital economy as we know it - but they are often unthought and unspoken.
What outsources and offshored forms of work are necessary to produce computers and smartphones?
How are race and gender relevant for understanding our daily usage of advanced technologies?
Indigenous circuits: Navajo women and the racialization of electronic manufacture.
Whither labor geography and the rise of the robots?
Social & Cultural Geography 18(3): 435-442.

You’ll be in groups of 3-4 for discussion - the make-up of these groups may vary throughout the term
The paper should be primarily critical/analytical in nature – it should not be primarily descriptive/summative

major_name: Bachelor of Applied Science Degree Requirements
topics: Introduction to International Development Fall 2023
Students obtain an overview of the multi-dimensional and transdisciplinary nature of development.

Themes include theories and strategies of development; history of development; relevance of context (culture, economics, and politics); the impact of law and international regulatory bodies; environmental influences; urbanization; the factors of health, literacy and violence; development agencies.
Reference is made to particular development problems in specific developing countries.
Discriminatory and intolerant language is unacceptable, but openness about these complicated issues is encouraged using thoughtful and respectful language.
You can expect the instructor to respond to emails within 48 hours exclusive of weekends and holidays.
To identify and critique the history of International Development concepts, theories, actors, and institutions.
To explain and assess key development issues in the field of International Development.
Is International Development legitimate?
Tentative guest speakers are also indicated in the schedule below.
Sep 21 Colonialism and Post-Development   Haslam et al.
Nov 24 Tutorial: The City Water Index & the multi-facetedness of development issues.
12 Nov 28 Democracy in Development   Haslam et al.
Introduction to International Development: Approaches, Actors, Issues and Practices.

major_name: Bachelor of Applied Science Degree Requirements
topics: B. Wylie-Toal
Email: bwylieto@uwaterloo.ca
This course uses the case study method to examine the challenges of starting, funding and operating an early-stage social change venture in a developing country.
Students explore the complexities of managing and sustaining growth, the role of governing boards, and the role of private sector partnerships and resources.
Environmental issues, including climate change, are some of the most pressing concerns of the 21st Century.
The first investigates the concept of green entrepreneurship.

The second part of this course explores the role of strategy and business models in helping to create financial value for the entrepreneur while simultaneously redressing the environmental problem at the core of the business.
Understand the central concepts of entrepreneurship in general, and green entrepreneurship more specifically
Apply that knowledge and gain experience in entrepreneurship by identifying, developing and proposing a concept for a new green venture
Recognize the challenges of navigating ambiguity and gain experience in self-managing your learning
Course Overview and Introduction to Entrepreneurship
Foundations: Systems Change, Social Innovation, and Green Entrepreneurship
Foundations: New venture life cycles and managing venture development
Milestones: The importance of problems and opportunity recognition
Milestones: Business strategy and business models
Milestones: Perceived legitimacy and the start-up pitch
Five of these activities will be for final grades and will be pass-fail.

As a class, we will use a stage-gate process to track and manage the progress of each start-up team, giving the whole class visibility into the pace of progress and lessons learned by you and your peers.
As part of the challenge, each team will complete a problem and solution brief, an overview of the strategy and logic behind the business, as well a business model for the new enterprise.
In addition to summarizing these details in a final report, each team will pitch their business to the class at the end of the term.
However, the team contract is due in September and the Pitch is due November 29th.

major_name: Bachelor of Applied Science Degree Requirements
topics: E-mail: c2mccord@uwaterloo.ca

This course emphasizes both theoretical and conceptual frameworks, techniques, practices and methods for analysis of development, focusing in particular on the development - environment interface and questions of sustainability.
View requirements for INDEV 602

This course emphasizes both theoretical and conceptual frameworks, techniques, practices and methods for analysis of development, focusing in particular on the historical and spatial trajectory of international development through an examination of seminal texts.
View requirements for INDEV 404
The course involves a mix of lectures and seminars that will involve weekly discussions of the assigned readings linked to case studies.
This course is designed to provide students with a critical understanding of: 1.
The meaning of theory
The meaning of development to different people, agencies and cultures
The ‘nexus’ between development theory and practice
5. Key scholars in the field of international development and their philosophical stances
The role and scope of different actors in international development practice
Understand the problem motivating the field of sustainable development
A Primer on Systems Thinking, Reflexivity and Critical Thought.
Establish the parameters for defining theory
Critically examine the nexus between theory and practice
Develop skills in systems thinking, reflexivity, and critical thinking

In pursuit of this aim, we will review systems thinking, reflexivity, and critical thinking as cognitive schemas to help us understand and evaluate these two dimensions of international development scholarship.
Investigate the construction of well-being as a concept
Critique the relationship between economic growth and well-being
Analyze the link between poverty and well-being

Overview: The subjectivity of well-being can make us feel confident that we know what well-being is when we see it, but that determination is entrenched in cultural presuppositions about the nature of well-being and the ways that well-being can be pursued.
In this week, we will explore different understandings of what well-being is and how that conceptualization of well-being can influence development theory and practice.
Understand the multidimensionality of development
Critique the relationship between economic growth and development
The reasons underlying this difficulty often stem from our own assumptions about the nature of development.
Those assumptions, very often, not only dictate the definition ascribed to development but also direct the path we choose in pursuit of that development.
During this week, we will confront the various definitions and dimensions of development and investigate how they relate to development theory and practice.
Understand the historical development of international development
Identify the precursors to sustainable development
Critique the trajectory of theories underlying international development
As a result, the history of development theory can feel like a swinging pendulum with revolutions, reactions and re-inventions defining the trajectory of the field.

During this week, we will explore the ideas and theories that have come to define the trajectory of development theory and how this history has defined the current conceptualization of sustainable development.
Evaluate sustainability definitions and criteria
Define sustainable development and its implications for development practice

In order to understand sustainability, and its relationship to sustainable development, there are certain cognitive schemas (like systems thinking) that can help to emphasize the often hidden implications of these two terms.
During this week, we will explore sustainability definitions and their relationship to sustainable development theory and practice.
Explain the relationship between disaster risk reduction and sustainable development
Evaluate the theoretical models underpinning disaster risk reduction
We will then critique the ways in which these concepts align and conflict with sustainable development practice.
Explain concepts used in sustainability assessment
Understand the role of community-based methods in sustainability assessment
Overview: How do we know if our current development practices are sustainable?
How do we take the theories, frameworks, and criteria that define sustainability and make them practical in our assessment tools?
As a means of guiding this discussion, we will use the frameworks available in community-based research and development methods.
As we will see in future weeks, the methods and approaches subsumed by community-based methods can provide a helpful guide for managing and monitoring sustainable development projects.
Discuss how power shapes development practice
Investigate the role of democratization in shaping development
Evaluate the role of community-based methods in shaping development governance
In this week, we will delve into this discussion and try to define power and its implications for development practice and thought.
This discussion will form the basis of our investigations into sustainable development governance and management.
Evaluate governance approaches in shaping sustainable development practice
Understand the importance of multi-level governance in sustainable development
Assess strategies for governing and managing sustainable development
Overview: So far in this course, we have established the complexity of sustainable development and the challenge of achieving the diverse criteria which have come to define sustainability.
As we have seen so far in this course, a systems approach to this challenge will be essential for understanding and appreciating the approaches discussed during this week in the course.
Apply established theory and ethical frameworks to the role of the development agent
Reflect on the appropriate skills and dispositions that the development agent should carry
Understand effective strategies for working with groups as a development agent
This week, we will explore how the theories and practices that define development can inform our own roles as development agents.
Understand the importance of futures thinking
Learn to apply futures thinking methods in sustainable development
Discuss the future of sustainable development practice
Overview: This week, we will look at the future of sustainable development by exploring an emerging technique that has important implications for development practice.
Futures thinking is a reorientation of our conceptualization of the future.
With this framing in mind, futures thinking seeks to orient our current choices towards the better and more sustainable future that we are working towards.

course_name: PLAN100 - Urbanization Today: Introduction to Cities and Regions (0.50)
major_name: Bachelor of Applied Science Degree Requirements
topics: Urbanization Today: Introduction to Cities and Regions Fall 2024
B. Doucet

Dr. Brian Doucet firmly believes that academic knowledge should be shared with wider audiences to enhance not only scholarly debates, but also political, policy, planning and public discussions about cities and communities.
He is a frequent commentator in the media and has experience and expertise speaking with a wide range of audiences about many important urban topics.
Dr Doucet’s first full-length documentary film Thinking Beyond the Market: a film about genuinely affordable housing, will be released in fall 2024.

His interest in cities and transportation began at an early age; his childhood home was within earshot of the Yonge subway line and as a child, he spent many hours watching trains from the bridge over the tracks!
He is particularly interested in the relationship between new transit lines and processes of gentrification and displacement.
His first book Why Detroit Matters (2017, Policy Press) examined counternarratives and inspiring visions in Detroit.
He was previously a competitive curler and represented the Netherlands at the European Curling Championships in 2008, 2010 and 2011.
This course considers the history of urbanization, models of urban and regional development, and ideals of good urban form in Canadian and global contexts.
Students will develop a critical perspective on the historical and contemporary relationships between processes of urbanization and broader societal trends and structures.
Introduction
We will explore different models of urban development, the role that shifting economic and social forces have played on the growth and development of cities, and different eras of urbanization.
Rather than only describing these changes, this course will introduce a critical perspective on the impacts of urbanization and urban change on marginalized groups.
The course will be taught through a combination of thematic lectures and case studies of challenges facing particular cities.

A key component of this course is to encourage and challenge students to look differently at the world around them in order to examine planning’s role in what we see visible (and invisible) in our cities.

Part One, The Growth and Development of Cities (weeks 1-6) explores different ideas and practices about how cities developed over time, as well as introducing different parts of the city (downtowns, inner cities, suburbs, mid-sized cities etc).
Learning Modes and Expectations:
The lectures will be given by Dr Brian Doucet and will introduce and explain key concepts, issues and examples.
The tutorials will be divided into smaller groups of around 25-30 students and held in the days following each lecture.
We understand that most of you are first-year students entering a new phase of your studies and that university education comes with very different expectation than other places of learning.
One of the main goals of this course is to develop critical thinking and observation skills in order to start your journey towards ‘thinking like a planner.’

As a result, we are more interested in your own thoughts, ideas and knowledge about a topic and how these can all grow throughout the course, rather than what you can find and produce through a generative AI software program.
Learn about the growth and development of cities through the history of urbanization and planning
Learn about the different parts of the Canadian urban system and how they have changed over time
Understand the impacts of key structures and processes in contributing towards social and spatial inequality
Develop skills related to note taking, lecture and reading comprehension
Develop skills related to observing aspects of change and aspects of the planning process within the built environment.
History of planning in Canada and other countries (History & Principles of Planning)
Forms, scales and settings of human settlements (Human Settlements)
Processes and factors of change in human settlements (Human Settlements)

course_name: PLAN341 - Ecology and Conservation for Planning (0.50)
major_name: Bachelor of Applied Science Degree Requirements
topics: Ecology and Conservation for Planning Winter 2025
This course provides students with a critical understanding of the relationship between human development and natural environments.
Students will develop an understanding of core ecological principles and how these can be taken up in plans and policies to promote nature conservation in urban and rural environments.

The course will include examples of how planners mitigate the environmental impacts of development of land, allotment of open space and parks, and conservation of sensitive areas and species in both urban and rural contexts.

INTRODUCTION
This is a course that explores the question, “What is the role of cultural heritage resources in urban and regional planning?”

Through class projects, students will learn about, and work with, the basic tools for inventorying and evaluating cultural heritage resources as well as some of the key legislative and policy tools available to them.

Challenge students to consider some of the practical, legislative, and ethical issues of practice

major_name: Bachelor of Applied Science Degree Requirements
topics: Statistics for Economists Winter 2025
ECON 221
ECON 221 001
Email: pchausse@uwaterloo.ca
Clinic: There is a clinic to help students with ECON 211 and ECON 221 every Tuesday and Wednesday from 3:00PM to 4:30PM in HH 235.
ECON 221:
This course introduces students to describing economic data and drawing inferences from features of economic data.

Starting from fundamental axioms of probability, students will learn about the calculation of probabilities of basic events and the features of random variables, the most important tool for representing the outcomes of complex economic phenomena.

Students will describe discrete and continuous random variables via their probability distributions and summary statistics such as means and standard deviations, as well as the relationships between two random variables in terms of covariance, correlation, and simple regression models.

The concepts of hypothesis testing and confidence intervals, and the fundamentals of statistical inference are discussed for basic features of random variables and for comparing the features of more than one random variable.

ECON 372

This course examines a number of topics relevant to financial practitioners.
View requirements for ECON 372
The purpose of this course is to provide students with advanced topics in corporate finance and their applications.

The key concepts and topics to be covered include security valuation, risk and return, risk diversification, capital asset pricing model (CAPM), investment performance measurement, financial derivatives, and forecasting.
Students will learn how to apply these concepts to real world problems using various examples and case studies.
The course deepens the general framework of financial landscape offered in ECON 371 by discussing the role of financial instruments and institutions in the economy.
The goal is to develop a deeper understanding of financial markets and investment strategies.
understand the need for firms and individuals to make financial decisions and together work towards overcoming the universal problem of scarcity;
appreciate the relevance of finance in a changing world;
explain why maximizing market value is the logical financial goal of the corporation
calculate and interpret some key measures of firm performance
understand and apply the Capital Asset Pricing Model
describe how options markets can be used to manage risk
identify different types of debt financing available to a firm
understand why investment decisions, rather than financing decisions, fundamentally determine the value and cost of capital of the firm
create pro forma income statements and balance sheets.

Design, draft and persuasively deliver scientific communications to expert and non-expert audiences.

major_name: Bachelor of Applied Science Degree Requirements
topics: Research Methods Spring 2023
Email: adam.mursal@uwaterloo.ca
An introductory survey of the research techniques commonly employed by sociologists, criminologists, and legal studies researchers.
The formulation of research designs appropriate to various kinds of intellectual problems in social science is stressed.
Comprehend fundamental research concepts and methodology (e.g., quantitative and qualitative research methods).
Readings and Videos
Introduction + General Research Orientations
Research Designs
Quantitative Analysis
Structured Observation and Content Analysis
Social Research Methods 6th Edition (Canadian Edition): 2022 Authors: Edward Bell; Alan Bryman; Steven Kleinknecht Yes

*An older Canadian edition of the textbook can be used, however, students are responsible for ensuring the appropriateness of course context and matching the related chapters to assigned weekly readings.
Assignment prompts: Must be 700-800 words in length, and are responses to a specific question provided as part of the lecture series.
Prompt 1 Question: What are factors that may influence what a person decides to research in the social sciences?
What are factors that might influence what you will propose to research in this course?
In your response, please provide a clear argument and discussion either for or against the use of covert research methods in the social sciences.
Students will create a study on a sociological/legal topic of their choosing that is both viable and realistic given the course context.

major_name: Bachelor of Applied Science Degree Requirements
topics: Field Research Methods Winter 2024
Email: kkpadda@uwaterloo.ca
** Please note that I won't be answering any questions regarding course material (for example - definitions of concepts, differences between theoretical perspectives, etc.) over email.
I believe that these types of questions are best discussed in person.
Office Hours: By appointment & via Zoom
This course provides a critical evaluation of research techniques in sociology, criminology, and legal studies with an emphasis on learning and applying qualitative fieldwork approaches.
Antireq: SDS 351R
Explain the nature and purpose of qualitative research in the field of Sociology and Criminology
Formulate research questions and draw connections to theoretical constructs that emerge from the data.
Recognize and critically evaluate ethical issues and considerations in qualitative interdisciplinary research and the implications of ethical decisions on participants, researchers, and communities.
Demonstrate understanding of theoretical, practical, and critical aspects of qualitative research.

By experimenting with different qualitative research methods, you'll develop an invaluable toolkit of knowledge and experiences that will be useful in the future - whether you're heading to graduate school, working in research settings, or designing projects in the workplace.

Students will complete the Tri-Council Policy Statement CORE-2022 course, which provides them with an institutionally recognized certificate of completion.
You will be conducting a preliminary analysis, including identifying themes and making connections to your existing disciplinary knowledge.
The research question should be something that can be observed, and you need to take detailed descriptive and analytic notes during the observation.
You will be formulating a research question that can be explored through online non-participant observation.
You will be revisiting your initial proposal submission and will be incorporating the feedback you received and the knowledge you have gained since the original submission.

As a final component of the course, you will be asked to submit a comprehensive reflection, which is open-ended and allows you to discuss your learning, challenges faced during the course, future goals, skills developed, and how you can communicate these skills to different audiences, be it academic or non-academic.
This course includes the independent development and practice of specific skills, such as critical thinking; synthesizing and analyzing information; developing and practicing writing skills.

major_name: Bachelor of Applied Science Degree Requirements
topics: Notice of Recording
Surveillance and Society Fall 2024
SEM
I am an Associate Professor in the Department of Sociology & Legal Studies and at the Stratford School of Interaction Design and Business.
I am in the second year of my master’s program in Sociology and Legal Studies.
Questions of a personal nature
Reviews of draft writing before submission
Every student is encouraged to introduce themselves to me before October 29 by attending a drop-in session and saying hello, or booking a one-on-one appointment.
An examination of the way monitoring technologies alter and shape social life in terms of security, fear, control, and vulnerability.

Some of the topics covered in the course include differential access and exclusion mechanisms enabled by online surveillance, predictive marketing using big data algorithms, racialized classification schemes and a host of monitoring technologies in online spaces, workplaces, and the home.
Readings will be drawn from the social sciences and popular media to facilitate critical inquiry into the shaping of popular perceptions about the surveillance and social control.
Communicate, describe, and debate topics related to how surveillance operates in social contexts, particularly how it comes to influence everyday life.
Analyse both academic and popular writing and reporting on surveillance and privacy, and synthesize core themes in written reflective summaries.
